comments.commentBody: This is an extraordinary piece of propaganda! It could have been written by one of the Dulles brothers. It consists mostly of made up "facts" and omissions. There is, as far as I know, no evidence that anyone associated with the Russian government hacked Podesta's emails. Nor did Russia act unilaterally to annex Crimea or start a was in eastern Ukraine. It did so only after the US engineered the overthrow of a democratically elected president in Kiev and installed a right wing puppet, who, by the way, threatened the autonomy of the Russian speaking region in the east. As to bombing civilians in Syria, there is nothing any proponent of US foreign policy can say about this that isn't laughably hypocritical . Over the past 15 years, since our entry into Afghanistan, it's been a good day when the US hasn't bombed civilians including clearly marked hospitals and wedding parties.. It's also worth noting that almost immediately after the US and Russia agreed to cooperate in Syria, the US attacked a column of Syrians regulars , thus scuttling the deal that the Pentagon publicly rejected. Putin's supposed expansionary vision comes down to this:  resist the forward march of US hegemony. Other than the US's  European vassals, most other countries agree. I don't know what Trump will do, but a foreign policy that relies on negotiation rather than relentless military posturing and the continued invasion of countries throughout the Middle East might be worth a try.

Shame on the NY Times! Why dont you just come out and say you want war with russia? That should be the title. And furthermore say your speaking on behalf of the declining american empire. Atleast than you would be honest.

This article is complete hogwash, pure propaganda. There is not one single line of evidence linking russia to wikileaks, and neither is there of the kremlin and trump. But like fox news apparently, you can just say what you like. What happened the last time major media drove home a false narrative on the threat of a foreign government? The war in Iraq. And didn't that just work out beautifully for all parties involved

Wow. I remember the 1980's when the press and Democrats were exclaiming that Reagan's tough stance with Russia would end in nuclear war. Now they are blaming Trump for being too soft on Putin. Putin saw weakness in Obama. The red line was crossed in Syria and Obama did nothing. Putin moved into Ukraine and took Crimea and Obama did nothing. Of course Obama was the one who mocked Romney about his 1980's view of Russia. Obama left Trump in a precarious situation in Russian relations.

President Vladimir Putin leads a nation of 143 million with a rapidly aging and shrinking native ethnic sectarian Russian Orthodox majority. America annually spends 8x more on it's military than Russia in a an economy with a nominal GDP 15x Russia. America has the #1 military by spending as much as the next eight nations combined. America has the #1 nominal GDP with 24% of the total with only 5% of Earthlings. The hacking was an asymmetric response to American hegemony.

America has many economic, military and diplomatic alliances. While Russia has very few. Russia has the largest land mass with numerous natural resources. Russia is not threatening American interests in the America's, Asia, Africa nor the Pacific region. Russia has a history of hostility with both the #2 and #3 economies China and Japan.

The danger of going hard against a wounded fearful bear like Russia is the real problem. Moving NATO and the EU closer to Russia is provocative and hard. Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria and Iran are a lot closer to Russia than America. Ukraine is a former Soviet republic that has deep ethnic sectarian ties to Russia. Russia has a growing native and neighboring non -ethnic Russian Muslim insurgency.

We will recall that during the campaign, when Trump began receiving security briefings, he pretty much dismissed what he had been told about Russia, notably its involvement in the DNC and Podesta hacks.

Now that he is President-elect, Trump is hearing, for the first time, the top secrets of secrets about our allies and foes around the globe. One wonders whether he can absorb this information, or will he be inclined to pay the information little heed. (He does, after all, know more about ISIS than our generals).

I can only hope that during one of these briefings, a CIA or NSA operative will state to Trump in a no uncertain tone: "Mr. President-elect, Vladimir Putin is definitely NOT your friend."
I will try to be circumspect here .... If you want to speculate on any position that the upcoming administration be taking on any issues, I think it would be wise to examine Mike Pence's stance.
Detente is better than friction and war and it is not a game.

This has all the makings of an experiement about to go wrong.
Mr. Trump in all his ego and inexperience, is about to find out the hard way, how the Russians play hard ball.
He'll lose.
And we'll lose with him.

Donald is going to leverage whatever or whoever crosses his path to forward the interests of Donald. We're in the age of 'Donald first' (with perhaps some sprinkles of pablum to quell the masses in his early years).

If that means that he rename himself, America, in order to fulfill his campaign promise of "America first", you can be sure that he will.

It's not about honesty, truth, and principles. It's about winning and winners, and the game of feeding the ego of the one surviving winner that emerges at the end of the battle for survival of the fittest.

The fact that that winner might have to lie, cheat, steal, and even kill to win is not a consideration. Round 1: Trump negotiates a deal with Putin on the premise that he can leverage Putin and ultimately win the position of 'top dog'. That is personal, not national top dog (there is a difference, that is, the Trump family business can succeed even if America fails). Odds are it won't be as easy as the conning, and manipulating of the American electorate.

Keep an eye out for traditionally friendly "allies" who Trump also thinks he can negotiate/manipulate to fulfill his personal agenda.
Perhaps Trump wants a Trump tower in Moscow.

"In many ways, Mr. Putin appears strong, but he is playing a weak hand, as Russia’s oil-dependent economy shrinks, its population ages and the country remains mired in costly military operations in Syria and Ukraine."

Russian aggression needs to be contained but the country is indeed in the grips of long term decline. The country to watch is China. Right now in ppp terms Chinese economy is slightly larger than the U.S.. But it is growing three to four times faster than our mighty economic system. In five years the World Bank, the IMF and the CIA, the most prominent statistical arbiters of comparative economic strengths see China with a 30 trillion dollar economy by the end of Donald Trump's current term of office (2021).

China will be well on its way to being a global superpower with twice the economic output of its most important rival the United States. How will we characterize the Chinese military in the 2020s? Parity, given the resources available to it, looks like an increasingly important probability. How do we manage relations with state whose economic and military resources match or in some ways exceed ours? This isn't a long term proposition. The assessment is at our doorstep.

I am heartened to see the many dissenting comments on this editorial. They have touched on most of the reasons why it is very important for the US to stop the propaganda campaign that has poisoned its population with a mindless, unquestioning fear of Russia that seems to trump all else. (Shame on the NYT and the entire main stream media for playing along with this.) There is just one thing I would like to add. By continuing the saber rattling, the US is greatly increasing the odds that Putin's successor will be a danger both to his own people and the US, and indeed to the world. Putin is no boy scout, but he is rational and pragmatic. Yes, he looks out for the interests of his country; that is his job. Yes, he is strategic and calculating, as any leader needs to be, but he is not crazy. By continuing to put fear and anger in the hearts of the Russian people, the US is helping to set the stage for someone far less restrained to take control in Russia. Is it worth the danger, just to keep the money flowing to our bloated military industrial complex? Think fearful, angry people will not vote into office someone who promises to address their fears and anger, even though their choice might put their country at risk in other ways? Please review, well, all of history, but also the events of the past week here in the US.
Mitt Romney made the same point 4 years ago, and President Obama responded with a snarky joke.

The foreign policy establishments of both parties long for a return to the Cold War. It was all so neatly binary and simple. Never mind that Russia has been reduced to a rump state with nukes and if it had a Lincoln instead of a Putin it would have taken Ukraine back years ago. The obsession with Putin demonstrates the continuing bankruptcy of foreign policy thinking in the United States.

Russia still has a massive nuclear arsenal. Going hard on them is probably the most dangerous thing anyone can do period. Making them angry and desperate is probably the worst possible thing we could do. Soft maybe not, tread extremely carefully, certainly. We surround Russia with bases, they have none around us. We are the ones with the most proxies. Russia does have a lot to complain about. The parts of the Ukraine occupied by Russians want to be part of Russia. The majority of people in the Crimea wanted to be Russian.  Russia is supporting the legal government of Syria, despite it being somewhat repulsive. Sorry this article shows that the liberal elite of our country think they should tell everyone in the world what to do and what is best for them. Russia and most of the world don't agree.
Cold-war war-mongering.

Progressives  weighing  in and agreeing with Trump. As the issues come out how much more can they agree  on? Can they work together? The nytimes  does not want it to happen. Even Obama  agrees Europe (Germany) is not paying it's  fair share. Can we proceed without obstruction? Or are we going to focus on Halloween  costumes  and Ivy League  soccer teams instead of the cost of prescription  drugs and defence spending. Or if Trump is for for you're  against it.
When are we going to see a 'danger of going soft on Iran' editorial, as the leading terrorist state continues to violate the nuclear agreement?

The editors assert that Russia "hacked" US elections.  That is a narrative expressed by the intelligence community; it offers no evidence and third-party investigation remains absent.  To call for presidential retaliation is arguably reckless and quite unfounded, but perhaps more symbolic of editorial political position than was its endorsement of the DNC candidate.  Indeed, was it really in fact endorsing that candidate? All the remaining editorial narrative could otherwise replace "US" for "Russia" and be a credible historical accounting, summary of US intent and consequences rather of US actions, than ones Russian.

Applause and congratulations to the NYT Editorial Board that has finally saw the light: one cannot always be a touchy-feely opponent of the warrior spirit, as NYT has consistently been in the discussions of the right to bear arms, but one must eventually get real in the world driven by greed, mistrust, cruelty, and hatred of thy neighbor.

The theme of this editorial is that reducing tensions between America and Russia is a bad thing.... bad for whom? Arms merchants?

I also think that to keep your readers well informed it would be good to present more of the issues that contribute to tensions, such as our withdrawal from the ABM treaty under George Bush, and the placement of American missiles in Romania and Poland.

Why on earth wouldn't we want Russia as an ally and partner in the world wide war on Islamic terrorism? Trump at least points out the obvious that we share their challenges to rebuild our own society from the inside. Russia would never invade us. ISIS on the other hand, has already done so.

I guess we need an external enemy to justify the costs of the military and the military- corporate complex. Russia fits the bill as it has since 1918 when we invaded it.

Add to those the concepts of American exceptionalism and America the indispensable nation and we create an environment for regime changing and world domination.

Our country is in turmoil right now because of the massive inequality and loss of blue collar jobs. This is what we need to concentrate on - job creation programs, health care for all, infrastructure needs. Spending on the military and ignoring the domestic front will only increase the turmoil. We need butter not more guns.
Under President Trump, U.S relations with Russia may become a modern day rendering of 'The Walrus and the Carpenter.' Pity the Oysters.

Possibly the oddest thing about the USA is the almost complete failure by its citizens to do any kind of self reflection. Have you ever thought how the USA might be the cause of any "threat" Putin poses to you? Who poses the greater threat - the country currently engaged in 120 illegal secret wars; the country building a 100 billion dollar drone bomb basis in Africa (we don't want you here); the country that caused the collapse in the Middle East with its illegal invasion of Iraq, the country inflaming Muslim hatred with its daily murders of them with illegal drone attacks, the country who consistenly fails to be held accountable before the law or Russia? Stop, just stop being so self satisfied. The world is not as the USA sees it.
